description: To carry out tree surgery, including crown reduction by 5 metres to 8 Hornbeams (T2, T3, T4, T5, T6, T7, T8, T10 - on the application), To reshape and balance one Oak (T1 - on the application), To reduce by 3 metres one birch(T11 on the application), all within Area 1 TPO 398
decision_conditions: Seven of the Hornbeams are situated within the rear garden, and One Hornbeam, the Oak and the Birch are situated within the front garden. They provide a gradual transition of mature tree cover between the dwellings in the copse wood estate and the nearby Ruislip Woods National Nature Reserve (NNR). The benefit in amenity and biodiversity afforded by the trees is both present and future because they have the potential for long life expectancies. As a result, they have a collective Moderate to High amenity value and significantly contribute to the arboricultural character of the Copse Wood Estate an Area of Special Local Character (ASLC).

The Hornbeams have not been pruned in the past, as a result they have attractive crowns typical of their species. The applicant has stated the reasons as to improve stability of multi stemmed and to admit more light, however no evidence has been provided that the trees are not "stable". A reduction by as much as 5m to the Hornbeams and a 3m reduction of
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.
